abstract.p: Accurate and reliable process measurements play a key role in the success of process control. In addition to selecting the instrumentation hardware, it is important to determine which variables should be measured in a process. Therefore it is important to study techniques for placing sensors on the processes. Dually the problem of placing actuators on the processes is equally important. In this paper, the problem of determining optimal sensor and actuator locations for the linear systems is addressed. The problem of the sensor locations is viewed as the problem of maximizing the output energy generated by a given state and for the actuator locations is viewed as the problem of minimizing the input energy required to reach a given state. Such design problems occur in many applications, and therefore have been studied extensively. Unfortunately, the results in this context, which have been proposed so far, only support stable systems. However, in industrial practices it is often the case that the system, which is needed to be controlled, is not stable. The method which is proposed in this paper is a general method in the sense that it supports both stable and unstable systems. The technique is successfully used for determining the optimal sensor locations of the linearized Continuous Stirred-Tank Reactor unstable model.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The technological world of today has been witnessing increased complexity due to the rapid development of process plants and manufacturing processes. Process control strategies cannot be applied effectively to such systems unless accurate and reliable process measurements are available. To this end, in addition to selecting the instrumentation hardware, it is equally important to determine which variables should be measured in a process. Therefore it is extremely important to determine sensor locations for the processes which need to be controlled (Van de Wal and De Jager, 2001). The important dual problem which needs to be addressed in the process control is the problem of determining the optimal locations for the actuators. In other words, the question is: what are the suitable variables to be controlled in order to control the processes effectively and efficiently? The actuator and sensor selection can be used to reduce the cost of operation and maintenance, even if all the variables can be manipulated and measured.

Several techniques have been proposed over the last few decades that take into account different performance criteria for the sensors and the actuators (Georges, 1995; Marx et al., 2002, 2004; Marx, 2003; Singh and Hahn, 2005, 2006).

One of the two most reliable methods for determining sensor and actuator locations is the improvement of state controllability and observability of the process (Van de Wal and De Jager, 2001). In these methods, the problem of determining the sensor locations is viewed as the problem of maximizing the output energy generated by a given state. The problem for the actuator locations is viewed as the problem of minimizing the input energy required to reach a given state. In Georges (1995), Marx et al. (2002, 2004) and Marx (2003) several Gramian-based methods from this category for optimal placement of the sensors and the actuators have been proposed. These methods have been improved and have been extended to nonlinear systems in (Singh and Hahn, 2005, 2006).

These methods find applications in various fields, and have been studied extensively. Unfortunately, the results in this context, which have been proposed so far, only support stable systems. However, in industrial practices it is often the case that the system, which is needed to be controlled, is not stable. The method which is proposed in this paper is a general method in the sense that it supports both stable and unstable systems. The technique is described and is successfully used for determining the optimal sensor locations of the linearized Continuous Stirred-Tank Reactor (CSTR) unstable model as an example.

The paper is organized as follows. In the next Section, we review the concept of the Gramians for both stable and unstable systems. The interpretation of the controllability and observability Gramians is also discussed in this section. Section 3 presents how Gramians can be used for determining optimal sensor and actuator location for a general system (stable and unstable). The numerical algorithm of the proposed method is also explained in this Section. In Section 4, the proposed technique is used for determining the optimal location of the sensors for a CSTR unstable model. Section 5 concludes the paper.

The notation used in this paper is as follows: M* denotes the transpose of matrix if M∈Rn×m and complex conjugate transpose if M∈Cn×m. λi(M) stands for the eigenvalues of matrix M . The standard notation >,≥(<,≤) is used to denote the positive (negative) definite and semidefinite ordering of matrices.

sec.title: 2. Controllability and observability Gramians
sec.p: The controllability and the observability Gramians are well-known matrices, which are widely used to check the controllability and the observability of the linear dynamical systems. The Gramians are also widely used in the process of model order reduction (Gugercin and Antoulas, 2004; Antoulas, 2005). For dynamical systems with the minimal realization: (1)G(s):=(A,B,C,D), where G(s) is the transfer matrix with the associated state-space representation: (2)x·(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t), x(t)∈Rn,u(t)∈Rp,y(t)=Cx(t)+Du(t), y(t)∈Rp, the Gramians are defined as: (3)P:=∫0 ∞eAτBB*eA*τdτ,Q:=∫0 ∞eA*τC*CeAτdτ, which are given by the solutions of the Lyapunov equations: (4)AP+PA*+BB*=0,A*Q+QA+C*C=0.
For stable A , they admit unique positive definite solutions P>0 and Q>0, which are the controllability and the observability Gramians respectively.

In equations (3), the integrals are unbounded for unstable systems, therefore these definitions cannot directly be extended for unstable systems. However, Lyapunov equations (4) may still have solutions for the unstable systems. In Kenney and Hewer (1987), Therapos (1989), Al-Saggaf (1992) and Chiu (1996), the Gramians for unstable systems have been defined as the solutions to the Lyapunov equations (4). These generalizations however have several limitations. First of all, the Lyapunov equations might not have any solution for unstable systems. Furthermore, if the solutions exist the cross Gramian PQmay have complex eigenvalues, which restricts the application of the Gramians. To cope with these problems, a generalization of the Gramians for unstable systems was proposed in Zhou et al. (1999).

Let X and Y be the solutions to the Riccati equations: (5)XA+A*X-XBB*X=0,AY+YA*-YC*CY=0, where (A,B) is stabilizable and (C,A) is detectable. Let F=-B*X and L=-YC*. The generalized controllability Gramian P and the generalized observability Gramian Q are solutions to Zhou et al. (1999): (6)(A+BF)P+P(A+BF)*+BB*=0,Q(A+LC)+(A+LC)*Q+C*C=0.
For the stable systems, X=Y=0, and the equations (6) are reduced to (4). Therefore equations (6) are general equations, which are useful for obtaining Gramians for both stable and unstable systems.

The generalized Gramians obtained from (6), similar to the ordinary Gramians are related to the minimum control energy and the minimum estimation error. In the sequel some time domain interpretation of the generalized Gramians are presented.

sec.title: 3. Optimal sensor and actuator locations for a general system (stable and unstable)
sec.p: In this Section, a method for determining optimal sensor and actuator locations is built upon the notion of the generalized Gramians.

It is well-known that the rank of the controllability/observability Gramians can be used to check if a system is controllable/observable. However, this is not enough for determining optimal actuator and sensor locations. To this end, several measures for the level of controllability/observability of dynamical systems have been introduced.

One measure which shows the degree of the observability/controllability is: (8)J1 o=minλi(Q),J1 c=minλi(P), where J1 o is the observability measure and J1 c is the controllability measure (Muller and Weber, 1972; Georges, 1995; Singh and Hahn, 2005). Higher values of these measures indicate a higher degree of observability/controllability of the least observable/controllable direction.

Some other measures use the trace of the Gramian or the trace of the inverse of the Gramian: (9)J2 o=trace(Q),J2 c=trace(P), where J2 o is the observability measure and J2 c stands for the controllability measure (Georges, 1995; Marx et al., 2002, 2004; Marx, 2003). The measure which uses the trace of the inverse of the Gramians are as follows: (10)J3 o=ntrace(Q-1),J3 c=ntrace(P-1), where n refers to the number of states of the system, J3 o is the observability measure and J3 c is the controllability measure (Muller and Weber, 1972; Singh and Hahn, 2005).For these measures also larger values of the measure indicate a higher degree of observability/controllability.
The determinant of the Gramian can also be used for the measure of the level of the observability/controllability (Muller and Weber, 1972): (11)J4 o=[det(Q)]1/n,J4 c=[det(P)]1/n,
A value of zero shows that the system is not observable/controllable. The larger values of the measure can be used as an indicator of the increased observability/controllability of a system.

Some measures make use of singular values for determining the degree of observability/controllability (Dochain et al., 1997; Waldraff et al., 1998). In Waldraff et al. (1998) the smallest singular value of the observability Gramian: (12)J5 o=minσi(Q), is used as one of the measures for determining sensor locations in tubular reactors. The dual measure for controllability would be: (13)J5 c=minσi(P).
This method is similar to the measure based on the smallest eigenvalue given by Muller and Weber (1972). Higher values of this measure show an increased degree of observability/controllability.

In Dochain et al. (1997), the condition number: (14)J5 o=max(σi(Q))min(σi(Q)), is used for the observability analysis of a fixed-bed bioreactor. The σ's refer to the smallest and largest singular values of the observability Gramian. A smaller value of the condition number generally implies increased observability of a system. Dual results hold for the controllability Gramian.

All these measures can be used in the process of determining the sensor and actuator locations. In this paper, however, the trace of the generalized Gramian is used as a convenient basis to present the level of controllability and observability.

The trace of the generalized observability Gramian is maximized when the output energy generated by a given state is in maximum value. Dually the trace of generalized controllability Gramian is maximized when the input energy required to reach a given state is minimum. These properties of the generalized Gramians can be used to formulate the problem of optimal actuator and sensor locations as the following optimization problems.

Optimal placement of na actuator and ns sensors for possibly unstable process is equivalent to determine B from: (15) {MaximizeB Trace(P)s.t.bij= {0,1 },∑i∈Ωbij=1, j=1,…,na where Ω is the subset of the state variables that can be manipulated and P is the controllability Gramian obtained from (6).

Dually for the sensor placement the problem is to determine C from: (16) {MaximizeC Trace(Q)s.t.cij= {0,1 },∑j∈Ocij=1, i=1,…,ns where O is the subset of the state variables that can be measured and Q is the controllability Gramian obtained from (6).
Note that it is not restrictive to assume bij= {0,1 } and cij= {0,1 } since the system can always be normalized.

The optimization problems (15) and (16) are integer programming problems. These problems can be reformulated for different controllability/observability measures presented in (8)–(14). For large-scale systems, integer optimization tools such as Branch and Bounds method can be used to reduce the computational burden of the algorithm.

sec.title: 4. Optimal sensor location for an unstable CSTR model
sec.p: In this section, the proposed method is used for determining the optimal sensor locations for the linearized CSTR unstable model. A CSTR in which the exothermic reaction A→B takes place is considered and the heat is removed by external cooling. The goal is to control the temperature T and cB which is the concentration of component B. The control variables are the feed flow rate F, the concentration of the component A in the feed (cAF), and the cooling water temperature (TC). The detailed model is a MIMO nonlinear model and is available in Hovd and Skogestad (1994). The model is unstable with: x= [cAcBT ],u= [TCcAFF ].

It is clear from (16), that the best choice in this case would be x2,x3 which is associated to the maximum of Trace(Q). In the case that we are allowed to use three sensors, the observability Gramian is: Qx1x2x3= (11880.0-5.512366.0-5.515.0-1.022366.0-1.02478.0 ), and its trace is 12363. As we expected it is more than Trace(Q) associated to the case that we use two sensors.

In the proposed approach the sensors are selected in such a way that they maximize the energy transmitted from the system to the controller or observer. This is done by selecting the sensors which maximize the trace of the generalized observability Gramians. For selecting the optimal actuator location as it is described in the paper, we have a dual procedure. In other words, the process consists in selecting the actuators that maximize the energy transmitted from the controller to the system. This is equivalent to maximizing the trace of the generalized controllability Gramians. Therefore this kind of control configuration selection helps to enhance the controlled plant behavior.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: A general Gramian-based method for determining the optimal sensor and actuator locations is proposed in this paper. The proposed method is the extension of its Gramian-based analogous counterpart, which has been proposed for stable processes. This method uses integer programming for numerical implementation. The method is applied successfully to an unstable model of a CSTR for the optimal sensor placement. Future research should include using more advanced Gramians for unstable nonlinear systems and also taking into account possible changes in the structure of the process.
